TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE ( GPE ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE at TIME the car of which the applicant is the registered owner was caught in GPE by a radar - trap exceeding the speed limit by CARDINAL km / h .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG Bezirkshauptmannschaft ) ordered the applicant pursuant to section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ( GPE ) to disclose within DATE the full name and address of the person who had been driving her car at the material time on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant replied that Mr PERSON [ first and family name in full ] , living in GPE , GPE had been the driver .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a provisional penal order ( Strafverfügung ) in which it sentenced the applicant under sections CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW to pay a fine of CARDINAL NORP schillings ( ORG ) with DATE imprisonment in default .
CARDINAL . The applicant filed an objection against this decision .

CARDINAL . NORP On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's objection and issued a penal order ( PERSON ) confirming its previous decision . It found that the applicant had failed to give complete information as requested in the order of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed on DATE submitting in particular that she had replied to ORG order , but had been unable to find out the exact address of Mr J.S. Further , she claimed that the obligation under section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW to disclose the driver of her car violated the presumption of innocence and her right not to incriminate herself . Finally , she pointed out that she was a NORP national and that NORP law did not contain a comparable obligation of the registered car owner to disclose who had been driving the car at a specified time .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Unabhängiger Verwaltungssenat ) dismissed the applicant 's appeal . As to the applicant 's complaint that the obligation under LAW of LAW violated the right not to incriminate oneself and the presumption of innocence , it noted that the relevant sentence of that provision had constitutional rank .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with ORG ) . She repeated the complaint as to the alleged violation of her right not to incriminate herself .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declined to deal with the applicant 's complaint for lack of sufficient prospects of success .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Verwaltungsgerichtshof ) refused to deal with the applicant 's complaint pursuant to section DATE of LAW since the amount of the penalty did not exceed ATS CARDINAL,CARDINAL and no important legal problem was at stake .
CARDINAL . The applicant was not prosecuted for exceeding the speed limit .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW as amended in DATE ( ORG ) provides as follows :
's right to require such information shall take precedence over the right to refuse to give information . ”

CARDINAL . The ultimate sentence of this provision was enacted as a provision of constitutional rank after ORG had , in its judgments of DATE and CARDINAL DATE quashed previous similar provisions on the ground that they were contrary to LAW which prohibits inter alia that a suspect be obliged on pain of a fine to incriminate himself .

CARDINAL . NORP In its judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG found that the first to third sentences of section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW as amended in DATE were , like the previous provisions , contrary to the right not to incriminate oneself which flowed from LAW and from LAW but were saved by the ultimate sentence of that provision which had constitutional rank . In reaching that conclusion ORG had examined whether the ultimate sentence of section CARDINAL § CARDINAL was contrary to the guiding principles of the constitution , but had found that this was not the case .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW , in the version in force at the material time , provided that a fine of up to ORG CARDINAL could be imposed on a person who violates the regulations of this Act .
